newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada's Avenor to sell Pacific Forest stake.
newsitem.headline: Canada's Avenor to sell Pacific Forest stake.

text.p: Canadian pulp and paper maker Avenor Inc. agreed on Wednesday to sell its 53 percent stake in Pacific Forest Products Ltd. for about C$573 million ($418 million).
Under the deal, Timber Trust, a unit of TimberWest, will acquire Avenor's stake in Pacific Forest for C$29 ($21.17) a share in cash.

A subsidiary of Doman Industries Ltd. will buy Pacific Forest's three sawmills, woodland tenures and related operations from TimberWest for about C$144 million ($105 million), including a proportionate amount of working capital.

Avenor chief financial officer Denis Aubin told Reuters the company expects to record an after-tax gain of C$100 million ($73 million) or C$1.40 ($1) a share in the fourth quarter when the transactions are completed. Net proceeds of about C$300 million ($219 million) will be used mainly to pay off debt, he said.
Definitive agreements on the transactions were to be signed by July 30, while the actual deals were expected to be completed by autumn, the companies said.

Analysts said Avenor appeared to get a good price for its Pacific Forest stake, which had been on the auction block since March when the company announced it was also seeking a buyer for its Gold River pulp mill in British Columbia.
"The values they got are in some respects above our number," said an analyst who declined to be identified.
Avenor's share price has been rising since its failed merger with financially troubled Repap Enterprises Inc. in late March as markets for its core products, newsprint and pulp, have improved.

In Toronto Stock Exchange trading on Wednesday, Avenor shares rose C35 cents to a new 52-week high of C$29.05, up more than C$10 from their level in December when the company announced its bid for Repap. Avenor shareholders rejected the merger in March.
Pacific Forest was up C25 cents to C$28.15 on Wednesday, while Doman class B shares were down C5 cents to C$9.20.
Avenor is based in Montreal, while Pacific Forest, TimberWest and Doman are based in British Columbia.
